annotation.TEXT: Oil Man is one of the more difficult of the Robot Masters in this game, if mainly due to his obnoxious pattern. Much like a good portion of the other bosses, the only thing he does is jump to set points - albeit, these ones being up against walls. He also tends to jump very high and move quite fast, which means you may end up missing a few shots if he suddenly dives out of the way (while shooting bullets and fire that ignites the lower part of the screen).

In any case, beating these optional Doc-Robots can actually give you a few upgrades of sorts. Defeating the one in Volt Man's level gives you an altered buster that produces two more shots every time your initial bullets hit an enemy (not that the game ever tells you this or gives you an indication, aside from the highly misleading Energy Balancer symbol over the boss selection).

The secret boss of each of these alternate paths is actually a Doc-Robot, who can (poorly) copy the patterns of two to three of the 8 main Robot Masters. This one is supposed to copy Volt and Dyna Man...but he's just as weak to the Volt Buckler as Bit Man was.

Oil Man's level essentially takes place in Oil Ocean Zone, more or less. Aside from a few new gimmicks being thrown in (and overly abused by the final room), this place is almost as uneventful as Torch Man's stage.

Shark Boomerang suffers the same fate as Flame Rush and Oil Igniter as being a rather lacking weapon, though perhaps not to the same extent. While it has a decent ammo count with multiple shots capable of being used at once, it still doesn't come anywhere close to being as useful as it should (mainly due to its weak damage output - which again, almost every weapon in this game seems to suffer from).

As eluded to before, the final section of this level is where things get out of hand. Anything and everything is spammed to a rather annoying extent here (especially with the Blader and Bolton enemies).
Oh, I'm sorry. Did I say Oil Ocean Zone earlier? What I obviously meant to say was Chemical Plant Zone.

Shark Man doesn't bring anything new to this game's bosses that we haven't seen before: He jumps, then he shoots, then repeats forever. He's not exactly difficult, save for trying to hit him with his weakness (as mentioned before, the Oil Igniter floats directly above you when fired underwater).

Ugh, why do these types of enemies even exist? Granted, they don't always show up in these fan-games - but when they do, they're easily one of the most annoying hazards around. They're even worse here, since unlike the ones in Spark Man's stage, these things just go back and forth on a set pattern (which basically means they turn around without any indication or having to bump into any kind of structure first).

Before I move on to the last two Robot Masters, I wanted to show the secret area of Volt Man's stage now that I have the requirements to enter. These paths that lead up to the alternate bosses are basically more difficult versions of the normal level, if partly due to other gimmicks being tossed in here and there.
What a surprise: They travel with you through screen transitions as well. It also doesn't help that these Peng enemies can literally spawn in almost every single part of this stage.

Shark Man's stage is just as boring as Torch Man's stage, with one particular exception: That being the slightly modified version of the Peng enemies that show up here (those flying penguins from the first Mega Man game). These things essentially act more like Medusa Heads now, popping up occasionally from the end of the screen to completely ruin your life in the most annoying way possible (don't be surprised if they knock you right into a pit on more than one occasion, or show up in a spot where you can't avoid them at all).

Oil Igniter is yet another weapon with not much going for it. It has a short range, it doesn't deal any more damage than the normal buster, and it floats upwards if you fire it while underwater (effectively making it near useless for its specific weakness affiliation against Shark Man). Much like Flame Rush, this thing isn't going to see much action in this playthrough.
